abstract.p: In an article in Das Ausland, Zacharias explains CD’s objections to a theory of heredity outlined by Marcus Cohen. The text is an excerpt from CD’s letter to Zacharias on the subject.

div.p: Ferner, dürfte es schwierig sein, Dr. Cohen’s Ansicht auf die Pflanzen zu erstrecken, obgleich die Gesetze der Reproduktion bei ihnen ganz dieselben sind, wie bei den Thieren. Ich halte die Meinung, daß von jedem der beiden Erzeuger ganz bestimmte Organgruppen des Embryos beeinflußt werden, für irrthümlich. Die Unrichtigkeit der Cohenschen Hypothese wird ganz besonders auch durch die Aehnlichkeit bewiesen, die reciproke Hybriden mit den beiden Eltern haben, durch die sie erzeugt sind.

Moreover, it would be difficult to extend Dr. Cohen’s view to plants, although the laws of reproduction are the very same in them as in animals. I believe the view that very specific groups of organs are affected by each parent is wrong. The incorrectness of Cohen’s hypothesis is also particularly demonstrated by the similarity that reciprocal hybrids have with both parents, from which they are produced.

div.note: The date is established by the date of publication of the article in which this extract appeared. The extract, translated into German, was quoted in the article.

In an earlier article, ‘Das Problem der Befruchtung und Vererbung' (The problem of fertilisation and inheritance; Das Ausland, 25 October 1875, pp. 856–8), Zacharias had outlined the theory of heredity found in an unpublished manuscript in the effects of a Dr Marcus Cohen, a deceased obstetrician from Hamburg. Cohen had argued, based on similarities he noted in the cell types, that certain organs of the body were formed from material in the egg cell, while other organs were derived from the sperm cell. In his letter to Zacharias, CD argued that this view could not account for parthenogenesis, or the ability of unfertilised eggs to develop into complete embryos in several species (Zacharias 1876).

Reciprocal hybrids are those formed from reciprocal crosses; that is, one hybrid has female parent A and male parent B, while the other has female parent B and male parent A. CD had discussed reciprocal crosses in both animals and plants in Variation 2: 65–72.
